front.title: Signaling that NSEC record owner name does not exist

abstract.t: DNSSEC was to large extent designed for off-line signing. A number of opertunites open up when on-line signing is used. In this case there is no real need for wildcard proof as the server can just say name does not exist. There are some applications that want to know if the name does not exist. This document creates a new DNS RRtype that can be used to signal non-existence of NSEC/NSEC3 record owner names.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: The DNSSEC Specification is largely designed for off-line signing with minimal thougth for as how on-line signing systems can give out smaller/better answers. One way to give a validatable answer for a question is to say name exists but the type does not. This works great for resolvers as they see what was asked for does not exist thus they tell the application that.
There is a a sub-class of applicaitons that mostly care if the name exists rather than the type, the question asked was to check for the existence of the name not the type.

To support both of the above behaviors we propose to define a a RRtype that has no body and never exists. When the the bit for this type is set the applicaiton can take that to mean "the right RCODE for this question was NXDOMAIN".

section.title: Protocol Changes
section.t:
This document specifies a special DNS RR Type that can only appear in NSEC/NSEC3 to signal:
this is an on-line signed answer and none of the owner name nor the target name or any name in between them exists. this name is not covered by any wild card
The purpose of this is to signal that the "right answer" was RCODE=3 and multiple NSEC/NSEC3 recods in authority section, but because the answer was signed on-the-fly we can pretend the query name exists but type does not, thus answerign with RCODE=0 and one NSEC record in the authority section. We call this RRType FakeNXDOMAIN or FDOM, type code is TBD.
An authoritative DNS server should not be exteneded to load this type.
A resolver can translate the returned NSEC record in a RCODE=3 answer if it so chooses, to clients that do not ask for DNSSEC answers.

section.title: IANA Considerations
section.t: We request an assignement in the "Domain Name System (DNS) Parameters" registry sub-registry "Resource Record (RR) TYPEs" for a type code FDOM (Fake DOMain name) suggesting reusing one of the never implememented type like SINK, NIMROD
